page.title: 01Upper Ettrick Valley
page.content: This upper stretch of the Ettrick Water, running SW to NE is flanked in the north by hills rising to 600mts and is cut through by many deep burns. The land to the SE of river and road is mainly planted with conifers, except for the high tops which are unplanted and ungrazed. Two farms each of about 1000 acres account for the other with Blackface sheep, producing top quality lambs for sale in September. Lambing is late in the upper valley, starting late April and lasting at least six weeks. The sheep are worked on a 6 year cycle with the oldest ewes sold to farms at a lower level for a final crop of lambs. The wool is clipped off the sheep in July. Hill cows, graze the lush growth of the summer hills, but fodder has to be bought in for winter which can be severe.
